{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3136288,"name":"Aron Rubin","username":"AronRubin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aronrubin/{size}/180072_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-30T15:42:14.068Z","cooked":"

My team has developed a microcontroller to preprocess sensor input and feed it through CAN. I think we are already conformant electrically and with FRC flavored CAN protocol with the exception of receiving broadcasts/heartbeats. However, we are having a bit of trouble discerning the best approach in WPILib for receiving data from a team developed device. The data will mostly be AHRS types. We also would like to know if there is a good way to structure such a project for building and distribution either within the robot code or as a library.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

FRC CAN Device Specifications

This document seeks to describe the basic functions of the current FRC ® CAN system and the requirements for any new CAN devices seeking to work with the system. Addressing: FRC CAN nodes assign ar...

That shows how to lay out the API ID’s to not colide with anything else, and to work with the WPILib API. Team devices show up as Team manufacturer (8) and Team device type (10). As long as your controller follows api format there, you can just use the CAN API to read things.

github.wpilib.org

CAN (WPILib API 2023.2.1)

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.wpilibj, class: CAN

We are starting with your frc_can_arduino library and adapting it to the rp2040 canbed dual device we are using. The question is there a smooth way of receiving those messages that jives with an otherwise typical robot?

I saw this but that seemed to be left without confirmation:

CAN Bus Java Documentation with Custom Sensors Java
There aren’t any simple wrapper classes for general-purpose CAN communication in WPILib, mostly because every device is a little different. However, you can technically call the FRCNetworkCommunication functions directly. It would look something like this, but you need to fill in the blanks for device-specific things. I’m also not sure if the message tokenization stuff will interfere with it. import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.IterativeRobot; import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.can.CANExceptionFactory; …

The high level CAN api I posted is the standard way, and has been the wrapper class to use since it was added I think around 2019 or so. You can just call readPacketLatest to get the latest packet, and its a non blocking API. It will give whatver the latest can packet received is for that ID. The 2 other API’s (New and Timeout) work similarly, but new only gives the newest packet, or none if none have been received since the last call, and Timeout will return the latest packet until timeout time has passed since the last packet, and then will return no packet. This is useful for determining if a device is still on the bus and sending packets.
